title: Differentiable Black-Box and Gray-Box Modeling of Nonlinear Audio Effects
author: Marco Comunità (Queen Mary University of London), Christian J. Steinmetz (Queen Mary University of London), Joshua D. Reiss (Queen Mary University of London)
relevance_why: The paper focuses on modeling audio effects using black-box and gray-box approaches, which could be useful in the audio processing tasks Haohe is exploring, particularly in generating and enhancing audio.
background: The study discusses advanced modeling techniques for nonlinear audio effects, such as compression, distortion, and fuzz, using differentiable approaches.
contribution: This paper introduces time-varying gray-box models for audio effects to improve accuracy and modeling range, achieving a better understanding of non-linear audio transformations.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on either black-box or gray-box models with limited generalization across different devices.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by comparing a larger array of architectures across diverse nonlinear effects, emphasizing time-varying characteristics that enhance flexibility.

key_innovation: The introduction of time-varying gray-box models allows for more accurate emulation of dynamic audio effects, enhancing both realism and computational efficiency.
real_world_impact: The findings could lead to more realistic and adaptable audio processing tools, benefiting both musicians and audio engineers in creating unique soundscapes.
limitations: The study may not adequately address the subjective experience of users across varying audio settings, potentially limiting its practical applicability.

new_terms.gray-box modeling: **Gray-box modeling** combines theoretical knowledge with empirical data to create models that are interpretable yet data-driven, useful in applications where complete system dynamics are unknown.

open_sourcing: Dataset ToneTwist AFx is available for community contributions.
